doom.driver: Trump's tariff regime has been ruled unlawful. What are the implications?
doom.blurb: SUPREME COURT NUKES THE TARIFF AGENDA
doom.summary: The Supreme Court struck down Trump's signature tariff policy, prompting him to immediately pivot to a 15% flat tariff 'effective immediately' — because when the ref blows the whistle, you just pick up the ball and run anyway. Meanwhile the Iran situation has gone notably quiet, no new ultimatums or carrier movements, suggesting we've downshifted from imminent-strike energy to tense-negotiation energy. The dominant story today is constitutional chaos dressed up as economics, with a $175 billion refund tab looming and Europeans apparently celebrating SCOTUS decisions more enthusiastically than Americans.

factors.name: Governance
factors.detail: SCOTUS striking down presidential tariff authority is a constitutional inflection point, but Trump's immediate workaround suggests instability rather than resolution.

factors.name: Geopolitics
factors.detail: Iran headlines have gone quiet relative to the 10-day ultimatum window, suggesting de-escalation or a pause — a meaningful drop from recent elevated readings.

factors.name: AI Capability
factors.detail: Karpathy discussing 'Claws' on HN and AI outperforming medical research teams are incremental capability signals, not alarming jumps.

factors.name: Alignment
factors.detail: ChatGPT flagged the Tumbler Ridge school shooter months before the attack but the system failed to prevent it — an alignment and safeguards failure with real-world consequences.

factors.name: Wild Card
factors.detail: Mississippi hospital ransomware attack shutting 35 clinics statewide is a reminder that critical infrastructure cyber vulnerability remains a background hum of doom.

dawn.driver: Giant tortoises return to Galapagos island after 150 years. More than 150 giant tortoises have been reintroduced to Ecuador's Floreana Island in the Galapagos.
dawn.blurb: EXTINCTION REVERSED: 158 TORTOISES RECLAIM LOST ISLAND
dawn.summary: In a world of tariff wars and geopolitical friction, humanity quietly pulled off a conservation miracle: species declared extinct by sailors 200 years ago now walk Floreana Island again. The reintroduction of 158 juvenile giant tortoises is the result of decades of patient scientific collaboration between Ecuador, conservation organizations, and local communities — proof that what humans break, humans can sometimes repair. Against a 31% doom backdrop, this headline stands as living, slow-moving evidence that deliberate, hopeful effort across generations produces real results.

factors.name: Science
factors.detail: Scientists successfully managed a multi-decade breeding and reintroduction program to restore a locally extinct species to its native habitat.

factors.name: Cooperation
factors.detail: Ecuador's government, international conservation groups, and local Galápagos communities worked together across borders and decades to make the tortoise return possible.

factors.name: Environment
factors.detail: Restoring a keystone species to Floreana Island will help regenerate native plant ecosystems that disappeared alongside the tortoises 200 years ago.

factors.name: Human Spirit
factors.detail: Norway's Johannes Klæbo won all six cross-country skiing events at the Winter Olympics, surpassing a 46-year-old record and demonstrating extraordinary human peak performance.

factors.name: Wild Card
factors.detail: Scientists may have found a triplet superconductor — a potential holy grail for quantum computing that could dramatically stabilize quantum systems and accelerate the technology.
